title: 108_hr2980
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Payment Update for Certified Nurse-Midwives Act". Congress finds that Medicare covers approximately 2 million women with disabilities of childbearing age, who give birth to 50,000 children annually. These women lack appropriate access to primary care services, with long intervals between gynecological visits and lower rates of receiving mammograms. Certified Nurse Midwives (CNMs) are reimbursed at 65 percent of the physician fee schedule, leading them to subsidize care or turn away patients due to financial constraints. Certified Nurse Midwives (CNMs) are facing financial challenges as professional liability premiums skyrocket, forcing them to leave the marketplace. Despite being highly educated and available to serve the population, CNMs cannot afford to operate at a financial loss. Certified Nurse Midwives (CNMs) are struggling financially due to rising professional liability premiums, leading to some leaving the marketplace despite their education and availability to serve the population. Certified midwife services are defined as services provided by a certified midwife who has completed a bachelor's degree and a program meeting guidelines prescribed by the Secretary. These services include those legally authorized under State law and incident to the midwife's service, similar to services provided by a physician. The heading in section 1861(gg) of the Act is amended to meet guidelines prescribed by the Secretary or certified by a recognized organization. The heading in section 1861(gg) of the Act is amended to include "Certified Nurse-Midwife Services; Certified Midwife Services". The Act is amended to include certified midwife services, allowing patients to receive care from certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives. The Act is amended to include certified midwife services, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide inpatient hospital services at teaching hospitals. The Act is amended to include certified midwife services, allowing certified nurse-midwives or certified midwives to provide inpatient hospital services at teaching hospitals, subject to certain conditions. The Act is amended to include certified midwife services for inpatient hospital services at teaching hospitals under the insurance program established by this title. The Act is amended to include certified midwife services for inpatient hospital services at teaching hospitals under the insurance program established by this title. Section 1833(a)(1)(K) is amended to increase payment to 95 percent for certified nurse-midwife services. Section 1842(b)(6) is amended to include assignment of payment for certified nurse-midwife and certified midwife services. The Act is amended to allow payment for certified nurse-midwife services in teaching hospitals. Payment can also be made to designated entities under an agreement. Section 1842(b)(7) is amended for clarification on payments for services in teaching hospitals. The Act is amended to allow payment for certified nurse-midwife services in teaching hospitals, even if they do not meet specific conditions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must create regulations within 180 days to implement the amendments allowing payment for certified nurse-midwife services in teaching hospitals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may issue interim regulations within 6 months to implement amendments allowing payment for certified nurse-midwife services in teaching hospitals.
